text: So we already have a risk management layer that's based on a small number of market variables that we applied to the tail hedge, tail river strategy. And it had worked okay, but it did not prevent some of the drawdowns that we experienced, which were painful in 2019, that we lost about 8% in that year. So while the market was up 30%. Now, as we observe each trade that it loses, we come up with a lot of ideas. You say, oh, is it because the treasury went up? Is it because we had a few days of mean reversal, or today it's also going to mean reverting? Or is it because the market went up too much before they opened? We have many ideas and speculation, but it is impossible to put them all together in a simple model to generate a risk management scheme. You have every day come up with ideas very soon, you have 100 ideas. How do you put all these 100 ideas together in a simple analytical model? Well machine learning does precisely that. You have a lot of ideas, great, throw them all in, let the machine tell you which idea makes sense. And besides, sometimes in certain periods, maybe these ideas work, and in other periods, maybe other ideas work, and they have this also conditional dependence. Maybe if you have a lot of ideas, you can put them all together. You can say, oh, the market went up because the interest rate went down, then blah blah blah. Or maybe if the fixed went up, but the market went also, then blah blah blah. So all this conditional dependence is extremely difficult for a human to hard-code into a model. But machine learning, especially random forest, is practically designed for that.
